Q: A father, in the process of teaching his son a lesson, gave him a bag of nails and told him that every time he lost his temper he must hammer a nail into their wooden fence. On the first day of this lesson, the little boy had driven 37 nails into the fence. He was really mad! Over the course of the next few weeks, the little boy began to control his temper and the number of nails hammered daily gradually dwindled down. He discovered it was easier to hold his temper than to drive those nails into the fence. Finally, the day came when the little boy didn’t lose his temper at all. He proudly told his father about it and the father suggested that the little boy now pull out one nail for each day that he was able to hold his temper. The days passed and the young boy was finally able to tell his father that all the nails were gone. The father took his son by the hand and led him to the fence. He said, "You have done well, my son, but look at the holes in the fence. The fence will never be the same. When you say things in anger, they leave a scar just like this one. You can put a knife in a man and draw it out. It won’t matter how many times you say I’m sorry, the wound is still there." What is the moral of this story?

Q: One day, a farmer’s donkey fell down into an old, dry well. The animal cried piteously for hours as the farmer tried to figure out what to do. Finally, he decided that since the animal was old and the well needed to be covered up anyway, he’d just bury the old donkey alive. He invited his neighbors to come over and help him. They all grabbed a shovel and began to shovel dirt into the well. When the donkey realized what was happening, he brayed loudly and kicked frantically. But soon, the noise stopped. After a few more shovels of dirt, the farmer looked down the well and was astonished at what he saw. With every shovel of dirt that hit his back, the donkey would shake it off and take a step up on the new layer of dirt. As the farmers continued to shovel dirt on top of the animal, he would shake it off and take a step up. Soon, to everyone’s amazement, the donkey stepped up over the edge of the well and trotted off!

So the man put the boy on the donkey, and they went on their way. But soon they passed a group of men, one of whom said: "See that lazy youngster, he lets his father walk while he rides." So the man ordered his son off, and got on himself. But they hadn't gone far when they passed two women, one of whom said to the other: "Shame on that lazy lout to let his poor little son trudge along." The man didn't know what to do, but at last he took his boy up before him on the donkey. By this time they had come to the town, and the passers-by began to jeer and point at them. The man stopped and asked what they were scoffing at. The men said: "Aren’t you ashamed of yourself for overloading that poor donkey of yours with yourself and your son?". The man and boy got off and tried to think what to do. They thought and they thought, till at last they cut down a pole, tied the donkey's feet to it, and raised the pole and the donkey to their shoulders. They went along amid the laughter of all who met them until they came to Market Bridge, when the donkey, getting one of its feet loose, kicked out and caused the boy to drop his end of the pole. In the struggle the donkey fell over the bridge, and his forelegs being tied together he was drowned. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: He who tries to please everyone pleases no one.
  choice: Look before you leap.
  choice: Too many cooks spoil the broth.
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
  choice: You can’t have your cake and eat it too.
A:
targets: He who tries to please everyone pleases no one.
multiple_choice_targets: Actions speak louder than words.
He who tries to please everyone pleases no one.
Look before you leap.
Too many cooks spoil the broth.
You can’t have your cake and eat it too.

Q: A father and his son were once going with their donkey to market. As they were walking along by its side, a countryman passed them and said: "You fools, what is a donkey for but to ride upon?" So the man put the boy on the donkey and they went on their way. But soon they passed a group of men, one of whom said: "See that lazy youngster, he lets his father walk while he rides." So the man ordered his boy to get off, and got on himself. But they hadn’t gone far when they passed two women, one of whom said to the other: "Shame on that lazy lout to let his poor little son trudge along." The man didn’t know what to do, but at last he took his boy up before him on the donkey. By this time they had come to the town, and the passers-by began to jeer and point at them. The man stopped and asked what they were scoffing at. The men said: "Aren’t you ashamed of yourself for overloading that poor donkey with you and your son?" The man and boy got off the donkey and tried to think of what to do. They thought and they thought, till at last they cut down a pole, tied the donkey’s feet to it, and raised the pole and the donkey to their shoulders. They went along amid the laughter of all who met them till they came to Market Bridge, when the donkey, getting one of his feet loose, kicked out and caused the boy to drop his end of the pole. In the struggle the donkey fell over the bridge, and his forefeet being tied together he was drowned. What is the moral of this story?
